review.title: A self-organizing system for urban traffic control based on predictive interval microscopic model
review.abstract: This paper introduces a self-organizing traffic signal system for an urban road network. The key elements of this system are agents that control traffic signals at intersections. Each agent uses an interval microscopic traffic model to predict effects of its possible control actions in a short time horizon. The executed control action is selected on the basis of predicted delay intervals. Since the prediction results are represented by intervals, the agents can recognize and suspend those control actions, whose positive effect on the performance of traffic control is uncertain. Evaluation of the proposed traffic control system was performed in a simulation environment. The simulation experiments have shown that the proposed approach results in an improved performance, particularly for non-uniform traffic streams.

sections.heading: 3. DECISION ALGORITM FOR TRAFFIC CONTROL AGENTS
sections.text: In this section, the main features and assumptions of the decision-making algorithm for control agents in a self-organizing traffic light system are evaluated.The goal of the system under consideration is to minimize delays in a road network by controlling traffic signals at intersections. System components are agents that detect incoming traffic, make decisions and take control actions independently for each intersection in the network.Pseudo-code of a decision-making algorithm for traffic controllers is then transformed into algorithm 1. Input data from the algorithm consists of parameters that describe incoming traffic flows. This data is collected by vehicle detectors on sections of the road that are inserted into the intersection. Output of the algorithm is a control decision that determines which traffic flow should receive a green signal. Successive control decisions are made in constant time increments. To make the control decision, the agent uses a traffic model to approximate the current traffic status and predict its future development.

sections.heading: 4. PROPOSED APPROACH
sections.text: In this section, details of the proposed self-organizing traffic light control for an urban road network are presented. A major innovation of the introduced method is that the control decisions are based on predictions derived from interval microscopic traffic models. Itallows analyzes the delays with their uncertainties for individual vehicles in heterogeneous traffic flows.

sections.heading: 4.1. Interval microscopic model
sections.text: The interval microscopic model of traffic flow combines cellular automation approach (Maerivoet and De Moor, 2005) with an interval-based representation of vehicle parameters. Due to the microscopic level of detail, the model can directly map parameters of individual vehicles. However, it means that the results of vehicle recognition can be directly taken into account in the decision making process. Cellular automats are used to simulate future evolution of traffic flows. Interval-based representation allows the model to take into account uncertainty related to vehicle parameters and driving behavior. According to this method, traffic flows are modeled in discrete time and space situations. A traffic lane is divided into segments of equal length, which are represented by cells in cellular automation. Traffic flows at an interface correspond to ordered vehicles. Each vehicle (i) in a traffic lane is described by its current position Xi (t) and Velocity Vi.

sections.heading: 5.1.1. SOTL
sections.text: The SOTL algorithm (originally SOTL Train in (Gershenson, 2005) uses a very simple traffic model that takes into account the current number of vehicles approaching a given traffic light at an intersection. Each traffic light (i) has a counter i, which is set to zero at red and then increases at each step by the number of vehicles approaching that red signal. To prevent the traffic light from switching too often, the following minimum green time restriction is used: a green signal i will not be converted to red if i < min, where i is the time since the signal i turned green, min = 5. Another limitation in the SOTL algorithm is the size of the boards. According to this restriction, a green signal i cannot be converted to red if i is the time the signal i turned green, min = 5.

sections.heading: 5.1.3. SOC_2
sections.text: The SOC _ 2 algorithm uses the interval microscopic traffic model to predict the cost of certain control measures. This algorithm applies the simulation-based prediction method introduced in Section 4.2. The predicted costs correspond to vehicle delays at an intersection and are presented in intervals. To select the control measures to be carried out, the SOC _ 2 algorithm finds a minimal element in a set of values corresponding to the centers of the cost intervals.

sections.heading: 5.1.4. SOC_M
sections.text: In the SOC _ M algorithm, the interval microscopic model is used to predict the green time required for vehicles to leave the intersection Gα and the number of waiting vehicles Nα (both of which are intervals in this case).The costs of control measures, i.e. the delay, are calculated in accordance with Equation (12).These calculations, however, are carried out using interval arithmetic, since the simulation results (Gα, Nα) are processed in the form of intervals. Finally, the evaluated cost intervals are analysed in order to make the control decision. This decision is made using the method presented in Section 4.3.

sections.heading: 5.1.5. SOC_2M
sections.text: The most recently considered algorithm (SOC _ 2M) includes all the new elements of the proposed approach discussed in Section 4. According to this algorithm, the delays (cost of control measures) are evaluated directly during the traffic simulation in the interval microscopic model. Cost intervals are not converted into numerical values, so the selection of control measures is based on the interval order approach.

sections.heading: 5.2. Road network model
sections.text: The simulation experiments were carried out using an enhanced version of the urban traffic model based on stochastic cellular automata (BBSS) originally presented in (Brockfeld et al., 2001). Topology of the simulated network is a square grid of 8 bidirectional roads with 16 signalled intersections. Connections between the intersections consist of 40 cells corresponding to a maximum distance of 300 m. At each intersection there are two alternative control measures: the green signal can be given to vehicles coming from the north and south or those coming from the west and east. A snapshot of the simulation scenario is shown in Figure 3.The urban road network in the BBSS model has square grid geometry. All roads are unidirectional. The dynamics of vehicles on the roads are simulated by using stochastic cellular automats with two parameters: maximum velocity vmax and randomized time parameters p.
